dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's a really big week for the market, um, with a ton of major companies reporting earnings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's a really big week for the market, um, with a ton of major companies reporting earnings.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its a big week for the market with a host of major companies set to report earnings as stocks pare back from near-record highs on rising concerns over the severity and economic impact of the deadly Chinese coronavirus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but, like, it feels like all that's getting overshadowed by, you know, the coronavirus situation out of China.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but, like, it feels like all that's getting overshadowed by, you know, the coronavirus situation out of China.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Typically during a week like this, all attention would be on earnings alone, but Chinas coronavirus is playing a huge role in the direction of stocks as the disease rapidly spreads with no vaccine in sight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. I mean, we've got Apple, Starbucks, Facebook, Amazon, even Tesla all set to report. But everyone's just grappling with the financial fallout.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. I mean, we've got Apple, Starbucks, Facebook, Amazon, even Tesla all set to report. But everyone's just grappling with the financial fallout.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its a huge week for earnings with Apple, Starbucks, Facebook, Amazon and others all reporting... and Tesla is expected to bring in $7.05 billion in revenue...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Amazon's expected to pull in, like, $76 billion in sales, and Tesla's got six billion-plus. Typically, that would be the *only* thing we're talking about.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Amazon's expected to pull in, like, seventy six billion dollars in sales, and Tesla's got six billion-plus. Typically, that would be the only thing we're talking about.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amazon is expected to report $86 billion in sales and earnings per share of $4.05, and Tesla is expected to bring in $7.05 billion in revenue and earnings of $1.65 per share.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But this coronavirus, it's, uh, playing a huge role. Especially when you consider Adam Crisafulli's point about the market already trading at pretty unsustainable valuations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But this coronavirus, it's, uh, playing a huge role. Especially when you consider Adam Crisafulli's point about the market already trading at pretty unsustainable valuations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Making things even riskier for investors is a market thats trading at unsustainable valuations, according to Adam Crisafulli, founder of Vital Knowledge, who says that the coronavirus is acting as an added headwind at a time when stocks are becoming extraordinarily sensitive to even the smallest setbacks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's just an added headwind. And you're seeing it, like, with consumer demand, tourism, especially during Lunar New Year. Forty million people on lockdown!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's just an added headwind. And you're seeing it, like, with consumer demand, tourism, especially during Lunar New Year. Forty million people on lockdown!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The spreading virus is already having an impact on consumer demand and tourism during the busy Lunar New Year period (almost 50 million people and more than a dozen cities are currently on lockdown)...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild. And U.S. companies with operations in China, they're feeling the pain too. Hotels, airlines, cruises, retailers â€“ they've all been hit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild. And U S companies with operations in China, they're feeling the pain too. Hotels, airlines, cruises, retailers - they've all been hit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hotels, airlines, cruise and casino operators, big retailers and consumer goods companies have all so far been affected by the financial impact of the coronavirus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And the market numbers reflect it, right? All three major indexes had a rough start this week. S&P down 1.7%, Nasdaq 2.1%. Dow saw its worst drop since 2018!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the market numbers reflect it, right? All three major indexes had a rough start this week. S and P down one point seven percent, Nasdaq two point one percent. Dow saw its worst drop since twenty eighteen!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 was down 1.6%, the Nasdaq Composite index 1.9% and the Dow Jones industrial average 1.5%. It was the Dows worst single-day drop since October 2, 2019, the S&Ps since October 8, 2019, and the Nasdaqs since August 23, 2019, according to Dow Jones Market Data.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh huh. Even crude oil prices hit a three-month low. Ryan Detrick said hopes for containment were squashed over the weekend. It's a "sell first, ask questions later" approach.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh huh. Even crude oil prices hit a three-month low. Ryan Detrick said hopes for containment were squashed over the weekend. It's a sell first, ask questions later approach.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Crude oil prices also hit a three-month low on Monday, with U.S. West Texas Intermediate falling to $53 per barrel. ... Hopes that the virus would be contained were squashed over the weekend, says Ryan Detrick, senior market strategist for LPL Financial. ... the bottom line is investors are taking a sell first and ask questions later approach right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Chris Zaccarelli from Independent Advisor Alliance, he's saying the Chinese economy, maybe even the world, will take a hit short-term.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Chris Zaccarelli from Independent Advisor Alliance, he's saying the Chinese economy, maybe even the world, will take a hit short-term.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Chinese economyand possibly the world economywill take a hit in the short run, and lower prices are a rational response to the increasing spread of the coronavirus, predicts Chris Zaccarelli, chief investment officer for the Independent Advisor Alliance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Which, like, makes sense given the spread. But he also brings up an interesting point about the medium term.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, like, makes sense given the spread. But he also brings up an interesting point about the medium term.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right! He compares it to SARS back in 2002. The S&P dropped 13% then, but by the end of that year, it was actually up 20% higher than where it started.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! He compares it to S A R S back in two thousand two. The S and P dropped thirteen percent then, but by the end of that year, it was actually up twenty percent higher than where it started.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Zaccarelli compares the coronavirus with the SARS outbreak: During the five-month period starting in mid-November 2002 until mid-March 2003, the S&P 500 dropped 12% but ended up actually finishing that year 19% higher than where it started, he notes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, potentially a buying opportunity, in the longer run, then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, potentially a buying opportunity, in the longer run, then?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, over the medium term, this will likely prove to be a buying opportunity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. A rough patch, but, um, maybe not the end of the world for investors who can ride it out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. A rough patch, but, um, maybe not the end of the world for investors who can ride it out.
